awd_titl_txt: Examining the Impact of Historically Black Colleges and Universities on Persistence of African American Women in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The project examines factors that influence the persistence of African American women in STEM that graduated from an Historically Black College or University (HBCU) by exploring National Center for Education Statistics datasets. The research project will use an intersectionality approach to study gender and race to better understand the experiences of underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines at HBCUs. The investigator used the National Postdoctoral Association guidelines to identify gaps in discipline-specific conceptual knowledge and STEM education research skills that would be needed to complete the research project and advance a STEM education research career. The investigator will implement a professional development plan to improve research skills in intersectionality research and mixed-methods research methodologies. Research skills will be enhanced through a mixed-methods research certificate program, institutes and workshops, mentoring from an advisory board, and conferences.  The proposed project will contribute knowledge about how the HBCU learning environment impacts STEM persistence among African American women and position the PI to become an active STEM education researcher.

The investigator will complete an exploratory project that examines patterns among African American women who completed a STEM degree at an HBCU using the two Postsecondary Education Transcript Studies. Use of the Baccalaureate and Beyond Longitudinal Study and the Beginning Postsecondary Students Longitudinal Study will allow data mining to conduct the analyses to answer he overarching research question: To what extent does HBCU attendance impact STEM persistence for African American women? The research will examine academic factors and financial variables that influence persistence. The study also will consider relevant policies to contextualize the study findings. The research will contribute to advancing knowledge of how the HBCU experience impacts STEM persistence and pathways to graduate education and the workforce for African American women. 

The project is supported through the EHR Core Research Building Capacity in STEM Education research competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported professional development activities for increased research method capabilities for future studies in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education research.  The principal investigator (PI), a professor in clinical psychology, sought to shift research areas from community education to mixed methodologies. To broaden capacity in STEM education research, the PI completed three professional development programs and worked with a team of consultants.  

The principal investigator completed an online mixed methods certificate program offered by the University of Michigan School of Social Work.  This four-week course served as a refresher to qualitative and quantitative methodologies. The program reviewed ways to integrate these two research methods, data collection methods and procedures and data analysis techniques. 

The PI's expanded review of the literature and methodological studies yielded a novel area of study for STEM education at historically black colleges/universities (HBCUs). After discussion with the consultants, the PI shifted the investigation to an unexplored area for STEM education with HBCUs. Thus, the focus was on the HBCU learning environment on African American Navy Reserved Officer Training Corps (NROTC) midshipmen.  

Further professional development was completed online through the American Psychological Association Advanced Training Institute: Research Methods with Diverse Racial and Ethnic Groups. The PI also completed the following courses at the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research through the University of Michigan: Math for Social Scientists, Statistics and Data Analysis I and II and Quantitative Methods with Race and Ethnicity I and II.

A literature review of HBCU best practices resulted in a draft semi-structured questionnaire for midshipmen, NROTC Commanders and HBCU STEM administrators.  After reviewing the draft document and questionnaires, consultants provided recommendations for revisions.  Results of the initial analyses were presented at the National Association of African American Studies Conference (NAAAS) and published in the NAAAS Conference 2021 monograph. Additional analyses were conducted and presented at the American Psychological Association annual conference through the Military Psychology division. A white paper was also developed to provide guidance for HBCU STEM administrators and was distributed to HBCU Navy ROTC Commanders and HBCU STEM administrators and university presidents where the NROTC scholarship is available. In addition, in consultation with an expert in African American military affairs and a data analysis expert, a questionnaire was developed to inform future research exploring African Americans' attitudes about military service.  

Principal Investigator: Yolanda K.H. Bogan, Ph.D.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Yolanda K Bogan
